skill.name: swift-development
skill.description: Comprehensive Swift development for building, testing, and deploying iOS/macOS applications. Use when Claude needs to: (1) Build Swift packages or Xcode projects from command line, (2) Run tests with XCTest or Swift Testing framework, (3) Manage iOS simulators with simctl, (4) Handle code signing, provisioning profiles, and app distribution, (5) Format or lint Swift code with SwiftFormat/SwiftLint, (6) Work with Swift Package Manager (SPM), (7) Implement Swift 6 concurrency patterns (async/await, actors, Sendable), (8) Create SwiftUI views with MVVM architecture, (9) Set up Core Data or SwiftData persistence, or any other Swift/iOS/macOS development tasks.
skill.summary: Comprehensive Swift development for building, testing, and deploying iOS/macOS applications. Use whe...
skill.author: hmohamed01

security_audit.summary: All 448 static findings are false positives. This is a documentation skill containing markdown reference files and helper shell scripts. The scanner flagged shell command examples (xcodebuild, swift, xcrun) in documentation as 'external_commands', Keychain API references as 'weak crypto', and GitHub URLs as 'network access'. These are legitimate patterns in a Swift development reference skill with no malicious intent.

content.user_title: Build Swift iOS and macOS Applications
content.value_statement: This skill provides comprehensive Swift development reference for building, testing, and deploying iOS and macOS applications. It includes command-line build patterns, testing frameworks, simulator management, code signing, and CI/CD workflows. Use it to quickly reference Swift syntax, Xcode commands, and Apple platform development patterns.
actual_capabilities: Build Swift packages and Xcode projects from command line with xcodebuild and swift build
Run tests with XCTest or Swift Testing framework and generate coverage reports
Manage iOS simulators with simctl for app installation, booting, and screenshots
Format and lint Swift code using SwiftFormat and SwiftLint configurations
Implement Swift 6 concurrency patterns with async/await, actors, and Sendable
Create SwiftUI views with MVVM architecture, Core Data, or SwiftData persistence
limitations: Does not execute Swift code or compile projects directly
Does not manage Apple Developer certificates or provisioning profiles
Does not deploy apps to physical devices or the App Store
Does not provide real-time debugging or crash analysis

use_cases.title: Build iOS apps from CLI
use_cases.description: Learn xcodebuild commands for building and testing iOS applications in CI/CD pipelines

use_cases.title: Create Swift packages
use_cases.description: Generate new Swift packages with proper structure, configuration files, and platform support

use_cases.title: Set up CI/CD workflows
use_cases.description: Configure GitHub Actions for building and testing macOS applications with multiple Xcode versions

prompt_templates.title: Build command help
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the xcodebuild command to build my iOS app for the simulator with release configuration

prompt_templates.title: Testing setup
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I run tests with Swift Testing framework and generate code coverage for my Xcode project

prompt_templates.title: Simulator management
prompt_templates.prompt: List available iOS simulators and show how to boot a specific device and take a screenshot

prompt_templates.title: Package creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Swift package with iOS 15 and macOS 13 support, SwiftFormat config, and SwiftLint rules

output_examples.input: How do I create a new Swift package with iOS support?
output: Create the package with: swift package init --type library --name MyPackage
Add iOS platform to Package.swift: platforms: [.iOS(.v15)]
Use the helper script: ./scripts/new_package.sh MyPackage --type library --ios
Configure SwiftFormat and SwiftLint with assets templates

output_examples.input: Set up CI for my iOS app
output: Use macos-14 or macos-15 runner for Apple Silicon builds
Build command: xcodebuild build -workspace App.xcworkspace -scheme App -destination 'platform=iOS Simulator,name=iPhone 15'
Test with coverage: xcodebuild test -enableCodeCoverage YES -resultBundlePath TestResults.xcresult
Extract report: xcrun xccov view --report --json TestResults.xcresult > coverage.json

best_practices: Use the included helper scripts (new_package.sh, run_tests.sh, format_and_lint.sh) for consistent workflows across projects
Configure SwiftFormat and SwiftLint with the provided assets templates to maintain code style consistency
Use Swift Testing framework (Xcode 16+) with @Test macros and #expect assertions for more expressive tests
anti_patterns: Avoid hardcoding simulator names in scripts - use environment variables or command-line arguments for flexibility
Do not commit generated files like .swiftpm/xcode or DerivedData to version control
Avoid using deprecated APIs like NavigationView for new projects - prefer NavigationStack with type-safe routing

faq.question: What Swift version does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill covers Swift 5.10 and Swift 6.0 patterns, with iOS 15+ and macOS 13+ minimum deployment targets.

faq.question: Can this skill compile and run Swift code?
faq.answer: This is a reference skill that provides documentation and examples. Actual compilation requires Swift toolchain installed on the system.

faq.question: How do I add code signing to my builds?
faq.answer: Use export options plists from assets/ExportOptions/ directory. Configure CODE_SIGN_IDENTITY and PROVISIONING_PROFILE in build settings.

faq.question: Does this skill work on Linux?
faq.answer: Swift Package Manager workflows work on Linux. Xcode-specific features like UI testing and simctl require macOS.

faq.question: How do I debug build failures?
faq.answer: Check references/troubleshooting.md for common errors. Use xcodebuild with -verbose flag for detailed logs.

faq.question: Can I use this with XcodeGen?
faq.answer: Yes. Generate your project with XcodeGen, then use xcodebuild commands from this skill for building and testing.
